newsitem.title: GABON: Priest set to be Gabon capital's mayor.
newsitem.headline: Priest set to be Gabon capital's mayor.

text.p: An opposition priest looked on course on Tuesday to become mayor of Gabon's capital Libreville after his party swept city hall seats contested last month.
Results of November 24 partial elections in Libreville issued by the local governor showed Father Paul M'Ba Abessole's Woodcutters' Party was ahead in all six city communes.
In the elections conducted on the basis of proportional representation, the Woodcutters outpolled President Omar Bongo's ruling Democratic Party in all six communes.
Results from Fougamou, the second town where partial elections were held, have not been announced. All results still have to be approved by the Supreme Court.

Elections reruns in the two towns followed the cancellation of voting there when chaos marred the main poll on October 20. The Woodcutters' Party and the Democratic Party won most seats decided after main poll.
Parliamentary elections due to have been held last Sunday were cancelled 24 hours before polls were to open because of logistics dificulties. A new date has not been announced.
